<div class="byline">
<p class="author-name" data-aid="159161352" id="p2">By President Jeffrey R. Holland</p>
<p class="author-role" data-aid="159161354" id="p3">Acting President of the Quorum of the Twelve Apostles</p>

<p class="kicker" data-aid="159161356" id="kicker1">God hears every prayer we offer and responds to each of them according to the path He has outlined for our perfection.</p>
</header>
<div class="body-block">
<p data-aid="159161359" id="p4">Brothers and sisters, I have learned a painful lesson since I last occupied this pulpit in October of 2022. That lesson is: if you don’t give an acceptable talk, you can be banned for the next several conferences. You can see I am assigned early in the first session of this one. What you can’t see is that I am positioned on a trapdoor with a very delicate latch. If this talk doesn’t go well, I won’t see you for another few conferences.</p>
<p data-aid="159161363" id="p5">In the spirit of that beautiful hymn with this beautiful choir, I <em>have</em> learned some lessons recently that, with the Lord’s help, I wish to share with you today. That will make this a very personal talk.</p>
<p data-aid="159161366" id="p6">The most personal and painful of all these recent experiences has been the passing of my beloved wife, Pat. She <em>was</em> the greatest woman I have ever known—a perfect wife and mother, to say nothing of her purity, her gift of expression, her spirituality. She gave a talk once titled “Fulfilling the Measure of Your Creation.” It seems to me that she fulfilled the measure of <em>her</em> creation more successfully than anyone could have dreamed possible. She was a complete daughter of God, an exemplary woman of Christ. I was the most fortunate of men to spend 60 years of my life with her. Should I prove worthy, our sealing means I can spend eternity with her.</p>
<p data-aid="159161369" id="p7">Another experience began 48 hours after my wife’s burial. At that time, I was rushed to the hospital in an acute medical crisis. I then spent the first four weeks of a six-week stay in and out of intensive care and in and out of consciousness.</p>
<p data-aid="159161372" id="p8">Virtually all my experience <em>in</em> the hospital during that first period is lost to my memory. What is <em>not</em> lost is my memory of a journey <em>outside</em> the hospital, out to what seemed the edge of eternity. I cannot speak fully of that experience here, but I can say that part of what I received was an admonition to return to my ministry with more urgency, more consecration, more focus on the Savior, more faith in His word.</p>
<p data-aid="159161375" id="p9">I couldn’t help but feel I was receiving my own personal version of a revelation given to the Twelve nearly 200 years ago:</p>
<p data-aid="159161378" id="p10">“Thou shalt bear record of my name … [and] send forth my word unto the ends of the earth. …</p>
<p data-aid="159161381" id="p11">“… Morning by morning; and day after day let thy warning voice go forth; and when the night cometh let not the inhabitants of the earth slumber, because of thy speech. …</p>
<p data-aid="159161384" id="p12">“Arise[,] … take up your cross, [and] follow me.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note1" data-scroll-id="note1"><sup class="marker" data-value="1"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159161388" id="p13">My beloved sisters and brothers, since that experience, I have tried to take up my cross more earnestly, with more resolve to find where I can raise an apostolic voice of both warmth and warning in the morning, during the day, and into the night.</p>
<p data-aid="159161391" id="p14">That leads me to a <em>third</em> truth that came in those months of loss, illness, and distress. It was a renewed witness of and endless gratitude for the resolute prayers of this Church—your prayers—of which I have been the beneficiary. I will be eternally grateful for the supplication of thousands of people who, like the importuning widow,<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note2" data-scroll-id="note2"><sup class="marker" data-value="2"></sup></a> repeatedly sought heaven’s intervention in my behalf. I received priesthood blessings, and I saw my high school class fast for me, as did several random wards across the Church. And my name must have been on the prayer roll of virtually every temple in the Church.</p>
<p data-aid="159161394" id="p15">In my profound gratitude for all this, I join G. K. Chesterton, who said once “that thanks are the highest form of thought; and … gratitude is happiness doubled by wonder.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note3" data-scroll-id="note3"><sup class="marker" data-value="3"></sup></a> <span class="page-break" data-page="8"></span>With my own “happiness doubled by wonder,” I thank all of you and thank my Father in Heaven, who heard your prayers and blessed my life.</p>
<p data-aid="159161398" id="p16">Brothers and sisters, I testify that God hears <em>every</em> prayer we offer and responds to each of them according to the path He has outlined for our perfection. I recognize that at roughly the same time so many were praying for the restoration of my health, an equal number—including me—were praying for the restoration of my wife’s health. I testify that both of those prayers were heard <em>and</em> answered by a divinely compassionate Heavenly Father, even if the prayers for Pat were <em>not</em> answered the way I asked. It is for reasons known only to God why prayers are answered differently than we hope—but I promise you they <em>are</em> heard and they <em>are</em> answered according to His unfailing love and cosmic timetable.</p>
<p data-aid="159161401" id="p17">If we “ask not amiss,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note4" data-scroll-id="note4"><sup class="marker" data-value="4"></sup></a> there are no limits to when, where, or about what we should pray. According to the revelations, we are to “pray always.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note5" data-scroll-id="note5"><sup class="marker" data-value="5"></sup></a> We are to pray, Amulek said, for “those who are around you,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note6" data-scroll-id="note6"><sup class="marker" data-value="6"></sup></a> with the belief that the “fervent prayer of a righteous [people] availeth much.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note7" data-scroll-id="note7"><sup class="marker" data-value="7"></sup></a> Our prayers ought to be vocal when we have the privacy to so offer them.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note8" data-scroll-id="note8"><sup class="marker" data-value="8"></sup></a> If that is not practical, they should be carried as silent utterances in our heart.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note9" data-scroll-id="note9"><sup class="marker" data-value="9"></sup></a> We sing that prayers are “motion[s] of a hidden fire,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note10" data-scroll-id="note10"><sup class="marker" data-value="10"></sup></a> always to be offered, according to the Savior Himself, to God the Eternal Father in the name of His Only Begotten Son.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note11" data-scroll-id="note11"><sup class="marker" data-value="11"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159161404" id="p18">My beloved friends, our prayers are our sweetest hour,<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note12" data-scroll-id="note12"><sup class="marker" data-value="12"></sup></a> our most “sincere desire,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note13" data-scroll-id="note13"><sup class="marker" data-value="13"></sup></a> our simplest, purest form of worship.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note14" data-scroll-id="note14"><sup class="marker" data-value="14"></sup></a> We should pray individually, in our families, and in congregations of all sizes.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note15" data-scroll-id="note15"><sup class="marker" data-value="15"></sup></a> We are to employ prayer as a shield against temptation,<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note16" data-scroll-id="note16"><sup class="marker" data-value="16"></sup></a> and if there be any time we feel <em>not</em> to pray, we can be sure that hesitancy does <em>not</em> come from God, who yearns to communicate with His children at any and all times. Indeed, some efforts to keep us from praying come directly from the adversary.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note17" data-scroll-id="note17"><sup class="marker" data-value="17"></sup></a> When we don’t know how or exactly for what to pray, we should begin, and continue, until the Holy Spirit guides us into the prayer we should be offering.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note18" data-scroll-id="note18"><sup class="marker" data-value="18"></sup></a> This approach may be the one we have to invoke when praying for our enemies and those who despitefully use us.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note19" data-scroll-id="note19"><sup class="marker" data-value="19"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159161407" id="p19">Ultimately, we can look to the example of the Savior, who prayed so very, very often. But it has always been intriguing to me that Jesus felt the need to pray at all. Wasn’t He perfect? About what did He need to pray? Well, I have come to realize that He too, with us, wanted to “seek [the Father’s] face, believe his word, and trust his grace.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note20" data-scroll-id="note20"><sup class="marker" data-value="20"></sup></a> Time after time, He retreated from society to be alone before piercing heaven with His prayers.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note21" data-scroll-id="note21"><sup class="marker" data-value="21"></sup></a> At other times, He prayed in the company of a few companions. Then He would seek heaven on behalf of multitudes who would cover a hillside. Sometimes prayer glorified His clothing.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note22" data-scroll-id="note22"><sup class="marker" data-value="22"></sup></a> Sometimes it glorified His countenance.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note23" data-scroll-id="note23"><sup class="marker" data-value="23"></sup></a> Sometimes He stood to pray, sometimes He knelt, and at least once He fell on His face in prayer.<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note24" data-scroll-id="note24"><sup class="marker" data-value="24"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159161410" id="p24">Luke describes Jesus’s descent into His expiation as requiring Him to <span class="page-break" data-page="9"></span>pray “more earnestly.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note25" data-scroll-id="note25"><sup class="marker" data-value="25"></sup></a> How does one who was perfect pray more earnestly? We assume that all of His prayers were earnest, yet in fulfilling His atoning sacrifice and through the pain that attended its universal reach, He felt to pray ever more pleadingly, with the weight of His offering finally bringing blood from every pore.</p>
<p data-aid="159161413" id="p20">Against that backdrop of Christ’s victory over death and His recent gift to me of a few more weeks or months in mortality, I bear solemn witness of the reality of eternal life and the need for us to be serious in our planning for it.</p>
<p data-aid="159161416" id="p21">I bear witness that when Christ comes, He needs to recognize us—not as nominal members listed on a faded baptismal record but as thoroughly committed, faithfully believing, covenant-keeping disciples. This is an urgent matter for all of us, lest we ever hear with devastating regret: “I never knew you,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note26" data-scroll-id="note26"><sup class="marker" data-value="26"></sup></a> or, as Joseph Smith translated that phrase, “[You] never knew me.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note27" data-scroll-id="note27"><sup class="marker" data-value="27"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159161419" id="p23">Fortunately, we have help for this task—lots of help. We need to believe in angels and miracles and the promises of the holy priesthood. We need to believe in the gift of the Holy Ghost, the influence of good families and friends, and the power of the pure love of Christ. We need to believe in revelation and prophets, seers, and revelators and President Russell M. Nelson. We need to believe that with prayer and pleading and personal righteousness, we really can ascend to “Mount Zion, … the city of the living God, the heavenly place, the holiest of all.”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note28" data-scroll-id="note28"><sup class="marker" data-value="28"></sup></a></p>
<p data-aid="159161422" id="p22">Brothers and sisters, as we repent of our sins and come boldly to the “throne of grace,”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note29" data-scroll-id="note29"><sup class="marker" data-value="29"></sup></a> leaving before Him there our alms and our heartfelt supplications, we will find mercy and compassion and forgiveness at the benevolent hands of our Eternal Father and His obedient, perfectly pure Son. Then, with Job and all the refined faithful, we will behold a world “too wonderful”<a class="note-ref" href="/study/general-conference/2024/04/13holland?lang=eng#note30" data-scroll-id="note30"><sup class="marker" data-value="30"></sup></a> to understand. In the name of Jesus Christ, amen.</p>
</div>
